abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Basic Education
            Project for Turkey were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            project design and scope can be appropriate to
            implementation capacity and significant efforts can be made
            to keep project design straightforward, simple and
            realistic. A realistic assessment of project duration during
            the preparatory stage, especially for the projects with
            large amount of civil works, can help to estimate project
            deliverables and impact more accurately. In the case of
            repeater or follow-up projects it is important to learn
            lessons, obtain evidence to evaluate performance and
            achievements from previous operations before asking the
            Government to commit resources for next operation. Roles and
            responsibilities of Government units and agencies regarding
            the projects can be made clear during project preparation.

TF030326-IRISH CTF FY03 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF030691-IRISH CTF FY05 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF038687-TURKEY:  BASIC EDUCATION APL I
            AND II,TF040181-TURKEY - BASIC EDUCATION APL I PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
In 1998, Turkey embarked on a program of
            poverty reduction on an epic scale. Virtually overnight, it
            extended compulsory primary school education from five years
            to eight. The program cost an average of 3 billion dollars a
            year. The World Bank chipped in with two phases of 300
            million dollars to finance different aspects of the reform
            where it felt its involvement will make a difference.

5086394.trustfund:
TF030691-IRISH CTF FY05 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF030326-IRISH CTF FY03 - EASTERN EUROPE,TF038687-TURKEY:  BASIC EDUCATION APL I
            AND II,TF040181-TURKEY - BASIC EDUCATION APL I PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Basic Education Project will
            support implementation of the Government basic education
            program, over the years 2002-2005, and builds on the actions
            supported under the first operation, through the development
            of preschool education, as an integral part of basic
            education and educational special needs. The project
            components will: 1) extend basic education coverage, by
            supporting continued rehabilitation, and extension of rural,
            and low-income areas' schools, through the construction
            of new preschool classrooms in existing basic education
            schools, as well as the renovation, and extension of schools
            for children with special needs; 2) improve basic education
            quality, through continued investments for schools'
            equipment, which includes computer facilities. The component
            will further initiate expansion of formal preschool
            education, and education for children with special needs,
            and, additionally, non-formal education, and early childhood
            development will be supported, targeted specifically for
            deprived households; 3) support in-service training in
            information, and communications technology (ICT) to teachers
            to improve basic computer skills, and assist in utilizing
            ICT to improve instruction, to inspectors to prod
            pedagogical ICT support to schools, and to assist computer
            instructors for the full utilization of ICT classroom
            potential. As the previous components, teachers of children
            with special needs, early childhood parents, and preschool
            teachers, will benefit from specifically designed training
            courses; 4) finance consulting services in the areas of
            project management, procurement aspects, financial
            management, including construction issues, equipment supply,
            and training needs; and, 5) support studies to assess
            program outcomes, particularly supporting semi-annual reviews.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Basic Education Project
            (APL) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Second Basic Education Project (APL) for Turkey. The
            plan for mitigating negative environmental impacts is as
            follows: During the construction phase, drinking water
            supplied at the refurbished schools will meet the standards
            laid down by the Turkish Standards Institution (TS226).
            Wastewater disposal will meet the environmental standards
            set for discharge into septic tanks and permission will be
            obtained from the municipalities regarding the wastewater
            collection system.Solid waste will be disposed of according
            to Turkish environmental regulations, the municipalities
            will be informed of the program schedule including details
            about waste quantities, and the disposal sites will be
            government-approved sites. In addition, there will be ad hoc
            training for some personnel who will be working on
            wastewater disposal and operating the equipment. Further
            training may be provided to ensure monitoring of compliance
            with the relevant environmental standards. The Ministry of
            Education will collaborate with other government agencies
            when needed to conduct monitoring and evaluation.
